extradition

whether, in circumstances where, pursuant to s 19 of the extradition act 1988 (cth) ( the act ), a magistrate has determined that a person is an eligible person within the meaning of that expression in s 22(1) of the act and has also specified the offences in respect of which extradition is sought and where all avenues of review of those decisions under s 21 of the act have been exhausted, it is an abuse of process and futile for that person to seek to set aside a subsequent determination by the minister under s 22(2) of the act that that person should be surrendered to the requesting country and a decision made under s 23 of the act to issue a surrender warrant on the ground that the issue of the relevant notice under s 16 of the act at a point in time necessarily anterior to the s 19 proceedings and s 21 review is invalid
leave to amend sought by the applicant to raise such a case refused
whether the minister was guilty of jurisdictional error when making his s 22 and s 23 decisions because those decisions were made under a misapprehension as to the facts and the law
applicant failed to establish that the minister's reasons included matters which were incorrect on the facts and the law
in any event, even if alleged misapprehensions existed, errors were within jurisdiction
no jurisdictional error established
s 16 notice not invalid in any event
application dismissed with costs
